resources.string: Knight - Moves in an L-shape (two squares in one direction, then one square perpendicular). Can jump over other pieces.
Rook - Moves any number of squares horizontally or vertically. Participates in castling with the King.
Bishop - Moves any number of squares diagonally. Each player starts with one light-square and one dark-square bishop.
Archbishop - Combines the moves of Bishop and Knight. Can move diagonally any distance or in an L-shape.
Chancellor - Combines the moves of Rook and Knight. Can move horizontally/vertically any distance or in an L-shape.
Queen - Most powerful piece. Combines the moves of Rook and Bishop - can move any number of squares horizontally, vertically, or diagonally.
King - Moves one square in any direction. Must be protected at all costs. The game ends when the king is checkmated.

• On larger boards, pieces maintain their standard movement patterns but have more space to maneuver\n• Custom pieces (Archbishop/Chancellor) add new strategic dimensions to the game\n• Experiment with different board sizes to discover new gameplay dynamics
Pawn - Moves forward one square, captures diagonally. On first move, can advance two squares. Promotes to any other piece when reaching the far side.

1. Players alternate turns moving one piece at a time
2. Capture opponent pieces by moving onto their square
3. The King must not be left in check
4. Win by checkmating the opponent's King
5. Special moves: Castling, En Passant, Promotion
